How to make AMP stories using Jekyll and Github Pages

Tap tap tap

The tappable web is an interesting place. These days discussion of tappable stories is dominated by Instagram. The Instagram stories format is, perhaps, the fastest growing media format of all time.

There are a handful of other story formats floating around. For example:

  • Twitter moments (example)
  • Instagram stories (example)
  • Giphy stories (example)
  • Medium series (example) (ironically these are user-hostile on mobile, forcing you to read them on desktop or in the native app‚Ä¶.)

In my mind, this whole genre started with Fish: a Tap Essay from Robin Sloan. And it recently got re-mastered! I strongly encourage you to check it out: https://www.robinsloan.com/fish/.

AMP Stories

To date, none of the tappable story implementations have worked well on the web but the closest is AMP stories. Until recently they were highly experimental and you had to get your domain whitelisted by Google to try them. But AMP stories just reached V1.0 and is now available for everyone.

So I thought I‚Äôd play around!

I should say before I go further that I do have some reservations about AMP. Namely:

  • I‚Äôm wary of AMP generally. I think the end result of AMP speeding up the web is a GOOD THING, but the centralization and move away from the open web is troubling.
  • AMP stories are still kind of clunky. There‚Äôs no swiping to advance. They‚Äôre just not as performant or smooth as native Instagram stories.
  • Google‚Äôs mishandling of cache problems and URL linking demonstrates a poor understanding of the web.

But, I like the way I can host story-format content on my own domain. So let‚Äôs play around and have some fun!

How do you build a CMS for tappable stories?

As I began thinking about making AMP stories and building some kind of generator for them I began to study the ‚ÄúCMS‚Äù of Instagram stories and marvelled both at the depth and complexity of it and how much is hidden beneath the surface. It‚Äôs an incredibly powerful platform that generates a huge array of types of stories without feeling burdensome.

For those that want a little more theory and noodling on web-based stories you should definitely check out Stephanie and Bryan Rieger‚Äôs explorations building hopscotch with Mozilla:

Rethinking the creative web: Our journey to reimagine ‚Äòweb publishing‚Äô for the social web

And for a more code-focused approach the team at Mic developed an open format called story-json that is designed to allow content to exist across multiple ‚Äústory‚Äù platforms. I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs actively maintained but it‚Äôs an interesting attempt at abstraction:

Introducing a cross-platform format for tap-through stories

In short - I have no idea how you‚Äôd go about building a web-based CMS to generate stories to the level of creativity you can get with Instagram stories but I‚Äôm sure someone will figure it out.

For me, I decided to build a bare bones generator that I could extend and play with‚Ä¶

Copy my code github!

Warning - there be dragons ahead! Badly coded dragons‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm not a developer or a designer so you‚Äôll see this whole thing is a little rough around the edges.

This blog is hosted on Github pages using the Jekyll framework. It‚Äôs a markdown heavy format but allows for liquid templating and while I thought about generating AMP stories using content blocks I decided using the frontmatter was a simpler approach.

How to use this to make AMP stories

The way I‚Äôve set it up - if you copy my layouts they work as follows:

The cover takes the following fields:

  • ‚Äútitle:‚Äù which is the main story title
  • ‚Äúsubtitle:‚Äù which is the subtitle
  • ‚Äúbackground:‚Äù which takes an image URL and makes a full screen background image

Then every page object works like this:

  • ‚ÄúLayout: thirds‚Äù divides the page into three horizontal rows of equal height to place HTML inside.
  • ‚ÄúLayout: vertical‚Äù allows for ‚Äústacking‚Äù of content but it‚Äôs not very sophisticated. Right now I‚Äôve set it up to have a top, image and bottom defined with the image taking up most of the page and full width. It‚Äôs crude but allows for in-line images.
  • ‚Äúbackground‚Äù takes an image URL and makes a full screen image background for the page
  • ‚Äúcta‚Äù takes two children, link and text which go to the link URL and the anchor text
  • ‚Äútextcolor:‚Äù which allows you to change the text color on the page to something other than default white
  • ‚Äúbackgroundblur:‚Äù when set to true it adds a filter:blur(2px) brightnesss(90%) to the background image

Two important notes for furthering creativity: the frontmatter supports emojis üî• and amp stories support gifs.

You‚Äôll see that this is all pretty crude and easily extensible. For more of an idea of what is possible take a look at CNN‚Äôs AMP stories.

Alternatively - I also made a super simple format that just takes a single input - a folder path. Then it generates an AMP story from all the images in that folder. See an example file here.

So! With all of that out of the way - what have I been playing around with? Here‚Äôs a few fun little stories I‚Äôve been using to test out the functionality:

Amazing Space Colony Art from the 1970s - this story is based on an article I read about this amazing space colony art that NASA commissioned in the 70s. Perfect space-gaping images for AMP stories.

Why you should read the left hand of darkness by Ursula K Leguin - I recently finished this book and thought book covers make for interesting AMP story content.

And if you want to peek under the hood you can see all of the raw files on github here.

Where next?

In summary - I think AMP stories have a long way to go before they feel anywhere near as fluid and fun as Instagram stories. The layout is more restrictive and there are lots of small interactions that just don‚Äôt work as well (little things like tap delays, no swiping, animations etc).

One feature that is especially clunky right now is adding links. But I‚Äôm excited that as of two weeks ago this project is being worked on to function much more like Instagram stories with a double-tap UI: https://github.com/ampproject/amphtml/issues/16521.

It‚Äôs still fun to be able to play around with this new kind of format on my own domain. And I‚Äôm excited for where things go next.
